poem:
**Urban Foxglove** 

The city unwinds,
gravel paths—stony veins—
yet out of their dust
a foxglove rises,
lambent against brick skies,
unnoticed but for mother's eye.
In its leathery defiance
blooms a quiet rebellion:
nature's hymn in urban key,
green fingers sing
where steel fingers grasp.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Country diary: My accidental, flowering tower block | Josie George I am deeply grateful to my green-fingered mother for teaching me what a young foxglove looks like. If she hadn’t, I might well have missed a June spectacle: the monumental wonder rising out of the dirty gravel of my tiny urban garden. In their first year of growth, foxgloves look like the kind of tough, leathery weed that will come to nothing, easy to pull". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
